subject: Fix shadowed variable issues
commitMessage:
Fix shadowed variable issues

This patchset is the conclusion of a multi-year effort to try to fix
shadowed variable names.  Variables seem to be shadowed all over, and in
most places they exist, there's a "code smell" of things that aren't
doing what the author intended.

This commit attempts to clean up these in several ways by:
1. Renaming variables where appropriate.
2. Preferring to refer to member variables directly when operating
   within a class
3. Rearranging code so that pass through variables are handled in the
   calling scope, rather than passing them through.

These patterns are applied throughout the codebase, to the point where
-Wshadow can be enabled in meson.build.

Tested: Code compiles, unit tests pass.  Still need to run redfish
service validator.

Signed-off-by: Ed Tanous <edtanous@google.com>
Change-Id: If703398c2282f9e096ca2694fd94515de36a098b

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 8a5928102841d34564c7f3fcd35e64d33638bff1

4 is the latest approved patch-set.
No files were changed between the latest approved patch-set and the submitted one.
Is there any downside here other than -Wshadow could be too strict? Will flag things that could be valid? A lot of these changes make sense

The only downside is when we do constructor variable naming, because of our coding standards, we have to do things like name variables "In" which we talked about elsewhere.  It's not a great pattern, but in the ideal case we start doing m_ prefixes for member variables and the problem goes away.

In short, it's a minor annoyance in that one case, but for most cases, shadowing a variable is at least a code smell we should avoid, and has caused bugs in the past.
I am good enabling this. I don't think it should cause developers much extra pain, makes the code more readable and might save us from some bugs
This makes me question why OpenBMC C++ guide suggests using camelCase everywhere including class data members.

-Wshadow isn't on by default anywhere nor enabled with -Wall (or even -Wpedantic).  It's obviously up to the maintainer here to decide if it should be enabled in order to reduce the trip-ups that are being encountered, but it isn't something we're necessarily enabling on the whole project.

> This makes me question why OpenBMC C++ guide suggests using camelCase everywhere including class data members.

My personal preference is that we use lower_snake_case because that more closely aligns with the larger C++ library community, but a long time ago we decided on camelCase (with an escape hatch for lower_snake_case in some cases).  Anyhow, we opted for not having suffixes and/or different case between all the various types/scopes because it implies a lot more importance than it actually has, makes refactoring more invasive, and [probably] adds just as much mess and noise as this sample code in the overall scheme of things.

A concrete example:
    auto foo = bar();
    
Is bar a function or a class constructor?  Does it matter?  What if I initially make it a class but later on decide to make it a function that returns some private type (or vice-versa)?

Normally there would be nothing wrong with continuing to use 'req' here except you've decided to enable -Wshadow, so now you're adding extra burden and noise on yourself.

> it isn't something we're necessarily enabling on the whole project.

FWIW, I've been chasing this down in bmcweb for several years.  Almost every time I've turned on -Wshadow it has found real functional bugs where someone set a variable in a scope that then got destroyed, where they were intending to set the higher scoped one.  If it weren't such a pain to implement in existing code, I'd be an advocate for making it universal across the project, but alas, we do what we can do.

>  including class data members.

FWIW, Emily a while back changed the standard we use to allow using prefixes on variable data members, so in theory we could, but that's not the kind of change I want to effect at this point with people already having a ton of tree-wide breaking changes recently.  At some point, it would be interesting to look at what it does and how much we could automate it with clang-tidy.

> My personal preference is that we use lower_snake_case

FWIW, this is my preference as well, and bmcweb at one point _was_ written in lower_snake_case.  As part of becoming part of openbmc, it needed to follow the coding standard, so it was changed tree-wide, as it removed a class of argument against its inclusion in the openbmc tree at the time.

>  Normally there would be nothing wrong with continuing to use 'req' here except you've decided to enable -Wshadow, so now you're adding extra burden and noise on yourself.

FWIW, the usage here in a constructor has also caused bugs in the past in the form of:

MyClass(std::string& string1):
   classMember1(std::move(string1)), classMember2(string1)
   
if string1In is used instead, it's clear which variable you're referencing.  You can still write the code incorrectly, but it's more obvious that it's an issue.
I was a big fan of using FWIW yesterday apparently.
Done
File really likes its single variable naming :(
I thought clang would want something more than a single char name
My patchset never merged;  It required clang-tidy-14, which... now that we have merged, we could probably get going if we rebased the patch.
